title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DALLAS – On a night where offense was a precious commodity, one man staged a clinic in basketball artistry. Gary Payton, the Seattle SuperSonics’ indomitable floor general, put on a historic performance, pouring in a staggering 42 points to single-handedly will his team to a 90-82 victory over the Dallas Mavericks.

In a grinding defensive battle, Payton was the lone supernova. While his teammates struggled to find their rhythm, "The Glove" was a picture of offensive efficiency and relentless aggression. He attacked the rim with ferocity, hit pull-up jumpers with cold-blooded precision, and orchestrated the entire Sonics attack. His 42-point outburst wasn't just a high volume; it was a masterclass in carrying a team on his back, accounting for nearly half of Seattle’s total points.

Dallas, led by a valiant 24-point effort from Michael Finley, simply had no answer. Every Mavericks run was met with a Payton counter-punch, a silencing three-pointer or a driving layup through contact that sucked the life out of Reunion Arena. Shawn Bradley’s presence in the paint, evidenced by his four blocked shots, was rendered moot by Payton’s ability to score from every angle on the floor.

This was more than just a road win; it was a signature performance etched into the legend of Gary Payton. On a night when little else worked for Seattle, their leader delivered one of the most spectacular individual efforts of the era, a 42-point tour de force that reminded everyone why he remains one of the game’s most formidable and passionate competitors.
